metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Rust Data Types
Data Types

Unlike many other programming languages, variables in Rust do not need to be declared with a specified type (like "String" for text or "Int" for numbers, if you are familiar with those from C or Java ).
content.html: Unlike many other programming languages, variables in Rust do not need to be declared with a specified type (like "String" for text or "Int" for numbers, if you are familiar with those from C or Java).

content.text: In Rust, the type of a variable is decided by the value you give it. Rust looks at the value and automatically chooses the right type:
content.html: In Rust, the type of a variable is decided by the value you give it. Rust looks at the value and automatically chooses the right type:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
let my_double = 5.99;   // float
let my_letter = 'D';    // character
let my_bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text = "Hello";  // string

content.code:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
let my_double = 5.99;   // float
let my_letter = 'D';    // character
let my_bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text = "Hello";  // string

syntax_highlighting.text:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
let my_double = 5.99;   // float
let my_letter = 'D';    // character
let my_bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text = "Hello";  // string

content.code_html:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
 let my_double = 5.99;   // float
 let my_letter = 'D';    // character
 let my_bool = true;     // boolean
 let my_text = "Hello";  // string

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let my_num = 5;         // integer
let my_double = 5.99;   // float
let my_letter = 'D';    // character
let my_bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text = "Hello";  // string

content.text: However, it is possible to explicitly tell Rust what type a value should be:
content.html: However, it is possible to explicitly tell Rust what type a value should be:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

content.code:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

syntax_highlighting.text:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

content.code_html:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
 let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
 let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
 let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
 let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let my_num: i32 = 5;          // integer
let my_double: f64 = 5.99;    // float
let my_letter: char = 'D';    // character
let my_bool: bool = true;     // boolean
let my_text: &str = "Hello";  // string

content.text: You will learn more about when you need to specify the type later in this tutorial. Either way, it is good to understand what the different types mean.
content.html: You will learn more about when you need to specify the type later in this tutorial. Either way, it is good to understand what the different types mean.

content.text: Basic data types in Rust are divided into different groups:
content.html: Basic data types in Rust are divided into different groups:

content.text: Numbers
Number types are divided into two groups: integer types and floating point types.
content.html: Number types are divided into two groups: integer types and floating point types.

content.text: Integer (i32)
The i32 type is used to store whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals:
content.html: The i32 type is used to store whole numbers, positive or negative (such as 123 or -456), without decimals:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let age: i32 = 25;
  println!("Age is: {}", age);

content.code:
let age: i32 = 25;
println!("Age is: {}", age);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let age: i32 = 25;
  println!("Age is: {}", age);

content.code_html:
let age: i32 = 25;
println!("Age is: {}", age);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let age: i32 = 25;
  println!("Age is: {}", age);

content.text: Floating Point (f64)
The f64 type is used to store numbers containing one or more decimals:
content.html: The f64 type is used to store numbers containing one or more decimals:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
  println!("Price is: ${}", price);

content.code:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
println!("Price is: ${}", price);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
  println!("Price is: ${}", price);

content.code_html:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
println!("Price is: ${}", price);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let price: f64 = 19.99;
  println!("Price is: ${}", price);

content.text: Characters (char)
The char type is used to store a single character. A char value must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':
content.html: The char type is used to store a single character. A char value must be surrounded by single quotes, like 'A' or 'c':

content.code_html:
let myGrade: char = 'B';
println!("{}", myGrade);

content.text: Strings (&str)
The &str type is used to store a sequence of characters (text). String values must be surrounded by double quotes:
content.html: The &str type is used to store a sequence of characters (text). String values must be surrounded by double quotes:

content.code_html:
let name: &str = "John";
println!("Hello, {}!", name);

content.text: Booleans (bool)
The bool type can only take the values true or false :
content.html: The bool type can only take the values true or false:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
  println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

content.code:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

syntax_highlighting.text:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
  println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

content.code_html:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
let is_logged_in: bool = true;
  println!("User logged in? {}", is_logged_in);

content.text: Combining Data Types
You can mix different types in the same program:
content.html: You can mix different types in the same program:

content.code_html:
let name = "John";
let age = 28;
let is_admin = false;
println!("Name: {}", name);
println!("Age: {}", age);
println!("Admin: {}", is_admin);
